results.title: Handle with care: glass
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A brief history of the Indian glass industry, contrasting the products of the individual artisan and the modern streamlined factory. To aid the industry, the Government established the Central Glass and ceramic Research Institute in Calcutta to conduct research into new types of glass.

results.title: Glassmakers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A survey of the wide range of glass products manufactured by British craftsmen. Includes manufacture of plate glass and installation of a large sheet in one of the Festival of Britain buildings; making of stained glass windows; manufacture of optical glass and lenses; prisms and lanterns for lighthouses; production of electric light globes; glass blowing and making of nahd0made cut glass.

results.title: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Film Associates

video_links.name: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers

results.brief_description: This 1960’s film is about the communication gap between two generations: teenagers and young adults on the one hand, and the generation of those over thirty - “the establishment”. The teenagers’ use of LSD and other drugs is only one of the symptoms of this communication gap. A group of parents desperately seek help in order to understand what has gone wrong. The film is an attempt to go “beyond LSD” and is intended to stimulate discussion amongst high school students, college students, teachers and parents. Ample involuntary hilarity can result from viewing this great hysterical/historical document. Starting as a raucous celluloid freak-out, the film presents its square’s-eye view of the “Generation Gap” through the fictive device of a round table of pod people, each alike in their helmet-hair and cat’s eye glasses. The production crew of this film was primarily made up of teenagers and young adults. Music by ‘The Stayns.’ A minor masterpiece of psychedelic cinema.
results.title_for_label: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers

results.title: Lost in Time and Space
results.brief_description: John Star is lost in time and space, a schizophrenic man from the 50th century adrift in the 20th. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: Glimpses of Australia. [No. 02?]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items include: 1. A lesson in geography - shows the size of Australia in relation to Scandinavia and Europe. 2. Warburton District - located on the Great Dividing Range, Victoria, shows scenery and inhabitants. 3. The Princes Highway - from Lakes Entrance to Narooma inlet. Shows Lakes Entrance locals and holiday-makers; an Australian First Nations person fishing with a spear; Narooma’s beautiful inlet; oyster fishing and eating. 4. Animal bandits - animals dance to the sound of birds; they form a band but their tunes are unbearable until they attend Professor Heron’s school of music.

results.title: Deserted landscape
results.brief_description: Material for this film was shot by the WEA Film Society in 1959 with the co-operation of various South Australian welfare organisations, with Ian Davidson as photographer and editor. It was subsequently made into a completed film, with commentary written by Nancy Cato, by Davidson’s company Arkaba Films in 1966. The project was supported by the Workers Educational Association of South Australia.

holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: The City's edge
results.creator_credit: Ken Quinnell, Errol Sullivan, Pom Oliver, Oliver Sullivan Productions, CB Films (France) and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dramatic contemporary love story of an aspiring young writer from the country and an urban woman struggling against the guilt of her first sexual experiences. They become involved with each other, their pasts and a frightening narrow world that is dominated by a charismatic young First Nations man who is driven by a contempt for life and a fierce hatred of white Australian society. Starring Hugo Weaving, Tommy Lewis, Shirley Cameron and Mark Lee. Co-starring Ralph Cotterill, Julie McGregor, Frederic Abbott, Martin Harris and Katrina Foster. Based on the novel by W. A. Harbinson.
